statement:
Loosely, the *Fundamental Theorems of Calculus* serve to demonstrate
that integration and differentiation are inverse processes. Suppose that
$F(x)$ is an absolutely continuous function on an interval
$[a,b]\subset\mathbb{R}$. The two following forms of the theorem are
equivalent.

[**First form of the Fundamental Theorem:**]{}

There exists a function $f(t)$ Lebesgue-integrable on $[a,b]$ such that
for any $x\in [a,b]$, we have $F(x)-F(a)=\int_a^x f(t) dt$.

[**Second form of the Fundamental Theorem:**]{}

$F(x)$ is differentiable almost everywhere on $[a,b]$ and its
derivative, denoted $F'(x)$, is Lebesgue-integrable on that interval. In
addition, we have the relation $F(x)-F(a)=\int_a^x F'(t)dt$ for any
$x\in [a,b]$.
names: fundamental theorems of calculus for Lebesgue integration
